docs.title: The Willowshore Ruling Family
docs.text: De facto rulers of a forgotten village, now facing an unwelcome change of power.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Type Noble family / Local government Location Willowshore Status Declining; resisting oni takeover Notable Members The Smiling One

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
For generations, Willowshore was a forgotten place—too small and poor to warrant attention from Shogun Tsuneni's regime in Jyito. In the absence of oni rule, a local family rose to become the de facto rulers, managing the village's affairs and maintaining order.

Now, with a new oni mayor arriving to claim authority, the family's position is threatened. They have refused to participate in the traditional Revival of Friendship—a ceremony meant to publicly put old grudges to rest and recognize the transfer of power.

docs.title: The Family's Shame
docs.text:
The ruling family carries a secret shame connected to the oldest story about the forest shadows. The tale's ending is never spoken aloud because it embarrasses them:

The heir to the family fortune was said to have been "lured away by forest spirits." In truth, he simply got drunk and wandered into the woods. The father—a teetotaler—spun the yarn about spirits to save face, and the family has maintained the fiction ever since.

This deception has created factions within Willowshore. Some villagers resent the family's dishonesty; others welcomed the oni's arrival as a chance to unseat the old rulers.

docs.title: Current Situation
docs.text:
The family's refusal to perform the Revival of Friendship is an act of quiet defiance—an unofficial protest against the oni's claim to have "always been here." But their position is precarious. They have lost their monopoly on power, and their old secrets may yet come to light.

With Magistrate Kurosawa's arrival, the family has been displaced from their estate entirely. They are now staying at Silver Mist Lodge, a faded inn on the riverside, while the magistrate occupies their former home. This public humiliation has only deepened their resentment.

The magistrate considered them the prime suspects for the warehouse fire that destroyed festival preparations. This suspicion proved correct: Migo, the family matriarch, admitted that "more brash" family members hired Hong to destroy the fireworks as a sabotage against the festival. She promised the party that all further planned disruptions would be canceled.

The family is also actively surveilling Magistrate Kurosawa, having tracked his repeated visits to the Mourndusk Willow in the Dark Woods. The glen where the tree stands is connected to a tragedy in the family's past.

docs.title: The Dark Woods
docs.text: The trees grow dense and the light grows thin. At night, the woods earn their name.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Type Forest Region North of Willowshore, Chu Ye Danger Level Moderate (day) / Extreme (night)

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
The Dark Woods lie immediately north of Willowshore, separated from the town by a clearing that contains the community graveyard and a few shrines. The forest is dense with deep green trees that grow thick and close together, blocking much of the light even during daytime. Within a few hundred yards of the tree line, visibility drops significantly.

The woods get their name from the dangers that emerge after dark. Willowshore residents universally avoid the forest at night, and the few who have ventured in after sunset have returned with stories of strange lights, unsettling sounds, and worse.

Despite this reputation, Willowshore has coexisted with the Dark Woods for many generations without serious incident—until now.

docs.title: The Mourndusk Willow
docs.text: Deep within the Dark Woods, but "not too deep" from Willowshore's northern edge, stands an extraordinary tree: a Mourndusk Willow.

docs.title: Appearance
docs.text:
• Black bark covering the trunk and roots
  • Black leaves that droop like a weeping willow
  • Deep, extensive roots that reach far underground and spread broadly
  • Unmistakable from the surrounding forest—entirely distinct from the regular willows that give the town its name

docs.title: Nature
docs.text: Mourndusk Willows are exceedingly rare "old earth trees" that cannot be propagated: - Taking a leaf or cutting produces nothing—they do not reproduce - They simply exist, remnants of ancient eons - Linked in folklore to dark magic, the occult, and cursed places - Said to be capable of poisoning the surrounding area and its animals - Despite this, Willowshore has existed near this one without apparent harm for generations

docs.title: Connections
docs.text:
• Magistrate Kurosawa has been visiting the Mourndusk Willow repeatedly since arriving in Willowshore. The Yeshou family has tracked his movements but does not know his purpose.
  • The glen where the tree stands is connected to a tragedy in the Yeshou family's past—linked to "the song that no one wants to finish."
  • Da Baishan's spirit lore found no connection to the spirit realm, despite the tree's occult associations.

docs.title: The Willowshore Graveyard
docs.text: At the edge of the Dark Woods, between the town and the tree line, lies Willowshore's community graveyard.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Family plots arranged in sections throughout the grounds
  • Small shrines in eastern architectural style (not western-style mausoleums)
  • Cricket cages — Small cages containing live crickets, placed at intervals throughout the graveyard. Their song is a traditional ward against restless spirits and undead. Standing near a cricket cage provides:
    • +1 to AC against undead
    • +1 on saving throws against fear and spirit effects
  • A grave tender maintains the grounds—a young woman in her 30s who was terrified when undead rose during Session Two

docs.title: The Undead Rising
docs.text:
During Session Two, the party encountered undead emerging from the graveyard for the first time in living memory: - A ghoul feeding on a recently exhumed body (someone who died within the past month) - A zombie shambling from between the graves - An undead cat lurking behind a tombstone

The grave tender and Donkey both confirmed this is unprecedented. Something is disrupting the natural cycle of life and death in Willowshore.

docs.title: The Ley Line Convergence
docs.text:
Migo revealed that Willowshore sits at a convergence of ley lines—arcane geomancy paths deep in the earth. Just as five rivers join on the surface, these invisible lines of magical energy cross beneath the village, creating a focal point that can be tapped to amplify magical power.

The Mourndusk Willow, with its ancient roots reaching deep into the earth, acts as a "lightning rod" for rituals that tap into these ley lines. This convergence is likely the true reason Magistrate Kurosawa was assigned to Willowshore—not just to oversee a political transition, but to exploit this magical nexus.

docs.title: The Summoning Ritual
docs.text: During Session Three, the party discovered evidence of a dark summoning ritual performed at the base of the Mourndusk Willow:

docs.title: Ritual Components Found
docs.text:
• A ceremonial steel dagger — Curved blade, ornate leather-wrapped handle, inscribed in Toanin (oni infernal language): "Let ancient law be sealed in the hand that guides Willowshore"
  • A clay bowl — Unglazed earthenware containing crushed moth wings (bodies removed) and traces of blood
  • A smooth depression — Between two roots at the tree's base, approximately two feet deep; the earth unnaturally smooth

docs.title: The Yellow Lichen Blight
docs.text: The ritual produced a lichen blight as a byproduct—a pale yellow, mossy growth that erupted from the east side of the tree in a blast pattern. Ginkgo (Nature 25) identified it as an arcane "bruise"—an after-effect of the energy released during the ritual, not a natural growth. The blight: - Was spreading to the tree's bark, roots, and nearby ground - Infected local wildlife (a bear and squirrels), giving them yellow eyes and aggressive behavior - Released sulfurous spores when disturbed (requiring Fortitude saves) - Could be neutralized by Ginkgo's fungal salve, turning it gray and causing it to flake off - The party fully cleansed the tree and surrounding area of the blight

docs.title: Willowshore
docs.text: A place of faded glory and stubborn heart.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Type Village Region Northern Chu Ye River Yanzy River Government De facto rule by local family; oni mayor arriving

docs.title: Regional Map
docs.text: Willowshore sits at the confluence of rivers, surrounded by dense forest. A lake lies to the east.

docs.title: Town Map
docs.text: The village features a central manor, torii gate with bridge, scattered buildings, farmland, and a graveyard. Dense forest presses in from the south.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Nestled on a slow bend of the rain-swollen Yanzy River, the town of Willowshore is a place of faded glory and stubborn heart. Here at the edge of Chu Ye's wild, mysterious forest, old festivals are honored even as old wounds fester. Strangers' footsteps are watched, and secrets settle thick as mist along the water's edge.

The town sits at a junction of rivers—once a thriving logging and mining hub, now a skeleton of its former self. The closest shore leads north to the sea; the rivers join together into a large lake to the east.

docs.title: History
docs.text:
Willowshore had a heyday long ago, but those days are past. The old industries collapsed, and the population dwindled. For generations, the village was too small and poor to warrant attention from Shogun Tsuneni's regime. In the oni's absence, a local family rose to become de facto rulers.

Now, after generations without an oni mayor, one is finally arriving—claiming to have "always been here." This has stirred unrest and reopened old divisions.

docs.title: The Revival of Friendship
docs.text:
A traditional rite observed at every change of power—whether a new store manager or a new mayor—where old grudges are publicly put to rest. It serves as an unofficial but very customary Transfer of Power.

The ruling family is refusing to participate in the ceremony for the new oni mayor. This defiance has created tension throughout the village.

docs.title: Festival of Returning Spirits
docs.text: An ancient festival held on the eve of autumn, meant to protect Willowshore from whatever haunts the dark woods beyond. The whole town gathers as lanterns flicker and drums thrum. Participants are chosen to lead a ceremonial play, walking in the shadows as the founders once did—acting out the fragile bargain that keeps the unknown at bay.

docs.title: The Forest Story
docs.text:
The oldest story villagers whisper about the forest shadows involves will-o-wisps that lead people astray into the woods.

Why no one speaks the ending:

The story's ending is never told aloud—not because it's forgotten, but because no one can agree on it, and speaking it starts fights. The disagreement runs deep, touching on old loyalties and resentments.

The truth, known to few: The ending embarrasses the ruling family. The heir to the family fortune was said to have been "lured away by forest spirits." In reality, he simply got drunk and wandered into the woods. His father—a teetotaler—spun the tale about spirits to save face.

This deception created factions. Some people secretly blame each other; some welcomed the oni as a chance to unseat the old rulers. One member of the ruling family (The Smiling One) whispers when they think no one is listening: "I know the real ending."

docs.title: Local Customs
docs.text:
• Averting eyes from oni: When oni enter town, lower classes must avert their gaze—only the ruling class may look upon them
  • "I've always been here": The official stance that oni have always been present, despite obvious evidence otherwise
  • Spirit death rituals: Local legend holds that death near a spirit requires special disposal of the body, lest it return or be controlled

docs.title: Cassian Voss
docs.text: A scholar of forgotten gods, now a forgotten ghost.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Name Cassian Voss Ancestry Human (presumed) Occupation Religious researcher / Scholar of "old gods" Origin Absalom (foreign continent) Status Deceased — spirit untethered Location Willowshore (spirit)

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Cassian Voss was a religious researcher from Absalom—a continent far from Tian Xia, making him one of the very few foreigners ever to pass through Willowshore. He arrived roughly two months before Magistrate Kurosawa, stayed for about a week, and then supposedly moved on to continue his research elsewhere.

In death, he appears as a translucent blue-white spirit—shimmering like heat haze off summer stone. Water drips from his face and the tattered sleeves of clothing that is distinctly not from Willowshore. He does not remember his own name.

docs.title: Research
docs.text:
Voss specialized in what he called "old gods"—elder deities that predated the current known pantheon across all traditions. His theory held that before the gods worshipped today, there existed a group of ancient, primordial entities—similar to how Greek mythology's Titans preceded the Olympians.

He came to Tian Xia specifically because its pantheon was unfamiliar to Absalom's scholars, and he hoped to find histories, oral traditions, or other links to these elder gods among the local religious practices. Very little is known about these entities, and Voss's work represented a rare scholarly effort to catalog them.

His research interests align disturbingly well with the dark summoning ritual later discovered at the Mourndusk Willow—a ritual that Migo identified as an invocation of the "Mother of a Thousand Wings", an ancient demon of pestilence.

docs.title: Death and Spirit
docs.text:
Voss was killed by a spirit at the river near Willowshore. Only Da Baishan and Ginkgo witnessed the death. Following Ginkgo's beliefs about the natural cycle, they hid the body in the forest rather than following local customs for spirit-death disposal.

Since then, Voss's spirit has appeared to Da Baishan and Ginkgo on multiple occasions:

  • During the graveyard combat (Session Two), the spirit appeared and shielded Da Baishan from the undead cat's attack
  • He spoke cryptic words: "You carry me into earth that is not my own. My ties bind beyond these roots. Something stolen, something broken."
  • He cannot cross to the afterlife until the mystery of his death is solved

docs.title: Personality (In Life)
docs.text: Based on Donkey's memories, Voss was a quiet, studious man who kept mostly to himself during his brief stay. He was noticeable primarily because foreigners from Absalom are exceedingly rare in this part of the world. He showed no signs of hostility or ill intent—just scholarly curiosity—and his departure seemed unremarkable at the time.

docs.title: Open Questions
docs.text:
• How did he actually die? — He was killed by a spirit, but what drew the spirit to him? Was his research into old gods the cause?
  • Is his death connected to the ritual? — His arrival predates the magistrate's, and his research into elder gods overlaps with the summoning of the Mother of a Thousand Wings
  • What was "stolen" and "broken"? — His spirit's cryptic message suggests something was taken from him and something was violated or destroyed
  • Did someone else benefit from his death? — Could the ritual have required a sacrifice, and was Voss that sacrifice?

docs.title: Hong
docs.text: A boy with firework dreams and a bag full of someone else's gold.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Name Hong Age ~10 years old Ancestry Kitsune Occupation Blacksmith's son / apprentice Location Eternal Blaze Ironworks, Willowshore

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Hong is Yong's young son—a kitsune boy of about ten years old, energetic and impulsive. He has a restless spirit and dreams of leaving Willowshore for open skies and wide seas, far from the dense forests and small-town life he's known.

Despite his youth, Hong is perceptive enough to recognize opportunity and desperate enough to take dangerous risks for his family's sake.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Hong is earnest, loyal to his father, and terrible at lying. When confronted by the party at Silver Mist Lodge, his attempts at deception were transparent—darting eyes, stammered excuses, and a visible urge to flee. Once he felt safe enough to talk, his words tumbled out with the unfiltered honesty of a child who knows he's in over his head.

He is not malicious. The warehouse fire was meant to be a "prank"—he genuinely did not intend for anyone to get hurt. He invited Kimmy along to "see the fireworks," not realizing the danger.

docs.title: The Warehouse Job
docs.text:
Hong was hired by the Yeshou family to destroy the fireworks stored for the Festival of Returning Spirits. The details:

  • Payment: 100 gold pieces
  • Instructions: Cause a "prank" that would disrupt the festival by destroying the fireworks
  • Method: Hong used kerosene to ensure all the boxes of fireworks would ignite at once, since lighting them individually seemed impractical
  • The girl: Kimmy was not part of the plan; Hong invited her along
  • The fire: Got out of control far beyond what Hong expected; the party rescued both children

Hong met with the Yeshou family alone. He does not know if they hired anyone else for similar jobs.

docs.title: Yong (Father)
docs.text: Hong idolizes his father and took the dangerous job specifically to help him. Yong has been talking about leaving Willowshore—he "sees dark skies ahead"—but lacks the funds to relocate and re-establish his forge elsewhere. The 100 gold would make that possible.

docs.title: The Party
docs.text: Hong is grateful to the party for rescuing him from the fire and for securing his payment from the Yeshou family. He trusts them, particularly Boone, with whom he had an extended conversation about life beyond Willowshore—open seas, wide skies, places far from forests.

docs.title: Boone

docs.title: Magistrate Kurosawa
docs.text: "I could make people do things. That's not what I want to do here."

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Name Kurosawa Title Magistrate Ancestry Oni Affiliation Shogun Tsuneni's regime Location Willowshore (temporarily at the Yeshou estate)

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Magistrate Kurosawa is a 7-foot-tall oni with striking blue skin and a fierce, commanding presence. He wears samurai-style lamellar armor and carries an enormous nodachi—a massive two-handed katana that most humans couldn't even lift. His very presence seems to command attention; he rarely needs to raise his voice.

He arrived in Willowshore a few days before Mayor Masru, taking up residence in the Yeshou family estate after displacing them. His stated purpose is to ensure the transfer of power proceeds smoothly.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Kurosawa projects extreme confidence bordering on arrogance—the certainty of someone who knows they hold all the power. Yet he is not simply a brute. He understands the value of diplomacy and soft power, preferring persuasion to force when possible.

He views the party as useful tools: outsiders without entrenched loyalties who can investigate without raising suspicions. He is direct about this arrangement—he does not pretend to be their friend.

"I could make people do things. That's not what I want to do here."

docs.title: Goals
docs.text:
• Ensure the Festival of Returning Spirits proceeds without incident
  • Establish oni authority over Willowshore with minimal resistance
  • Identify and neutralize potential sources of dissent
  • Prepare for Mayor Masru's arrival
  • Unknown purpose at the Mourndusk Willow — He has been making repeated visits to an ancient tree in the Dark Woods; his reasons remain a mystery

docs.title: The Party
docs.text: Kurosawa recruited the party as his deputies, paying them 50 gold up front with 50 more promised upon successful completion of their duties. He sees them as expendable assets who can do the groundwork he cannot—moving among the common folk without inspiring the same fear and silence that follows him.

docs.title: The Yeshou Family
docs.text: He views the Willowshore Ruling Family as the most obvious threat to a smooth transition. He displaced them from their estate and suggested the party investigate them first.

docs.title: Mayor Masru
docs.text: The oni mayor claiming authority over a village that has governed itself for generations.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Name Masru Title Mayor of Willowshore Ancestry Oni Affiliation Shogun Tsuneni's regime Status Expected to arrive during the Festival of Returning Spirits

Not Yet Appeared

Mayor Masru has not yet arrived in Willowshore. This entry contains only what is known or rumored about him.

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
For generations, Willowshore was too small and poor to warrant attention from the oni regime. The village governed itself under the de facto rule of a local family. Now, seemingly out of nowhere, an oni mayor has been appointed to take control.

According to oni custom, Mayor Masru will arrive claiming to have "always been here"—the pretense that oni authority is eternal and uninterrupted, even when they've been absent for decades.

docs.title: Arrival
docs.text:
Masru is expected to arrive the evening of the Festival of Returning Spirits. Magistrate Kurosawa has been sent ahead to prepare the town and ensure the transfer of power proceeds smoothly.

The Willowshore Ruling Family is refusing to participate in the traditional Revival of Friendship ceremony—the customary rite where old grudges are publicly put to rest to welcome new leadership. This defiance has created tension throughout the village.

docs.title: Significance
docs.text:
Masru's arrival represents the first direct oni rule over Willowshore in living memory. Some villagers see this as an opportunity—the oni are the ruling class, and currying favor could raise their station. Others view it as an invasion, a theft of their autonomy by a regime that ignored them for generations.

The timing of the warehouse fire—destroying festival preparations the day before Masru's arrival—has raised suspicions of sabotage.

docs.text: The old woman smokes, drinks, and runs Willowshore's most powerful family from a borrowed room in a faded inn.

docs.text: Name Migo Title Matriarch / Elder Ancestry Human (elderly) Affiliation Willowshore Ruling Family (Yeshou family) Location Silver Mist Lodge, Willowshore (temporarily)

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Migo is the matriarch of the Yeshou family—the de facto ruling family of Willowshore. She is elderly, possibly ancient, having been alive during the family's founding era. She holds court in a darkened suite at Silver Mist Lodge, curtains drawn, wreathed in tobacco smoke, flanked by two guards who are family retainers rather than blood relatives.

She has a piercing gaze and projects quiet, absolute authority. She drinks and smokes with the unhurried ease of someone who has outlasted most of her problems.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Migo is sharp, pragmatic, and honest when it serves her interests. She does not posture or waste words. When confronted with the party's evidence of her family's sabotage, she admitted it immediately—calling it a "foolish endeavor" by "more brash" members—rather than wasting time on denials.

She values honesty in return. Da Baishan's straightforward admission that the party was working under the magistrate's orders, but unwillingly, earned her respect and cooperation.

She is protective of her family's legacy and deeply opposed to the oni takeover, but she understands when a gambit has failed and cuts her losses cleanly.

• Preserve the Yeshou family's influence in Willowshore during the transition of power
  • Monitor Magistrate Kurosawa's activities, particularly his visits to the Dark Woods
  • Prevent further embarrassment to the family after the botched warehouse sabotage
  • Understand what Kurosawa wants with the Mourndusk Willow

docs.title: The Party
docs.text: Migo was impressed by the party's honesty and directness. She shared intelligence about Kurosawa's movements and honored the 100 gold payment to Hong as promised. She expressed hope for "further conversations and a deeper understanding" with the group.

docs.title: Magistrate Kurosawa
docs.text: She views him with deep suspicion. Her family has been tracking his movements and discovered his repeated visits to the Mourndusk Willow in the Dark Woods. She warned the party that he is "accomplished in the arcane arts" and "not exactly what he seems."

docs.title: Littlefinger
docs.text: She knows Littlefinger through his family connection. She apologized to him specifically for his injuries in the fire, calling them "scratches" with dry understatement.

docs.title: Hong
docs.text: She took advantage of Hong's desperation, hiring a child to do dangerous work. She acknowledged this was dishonorable and chose to honor the payment regardless.

docs.title: Radiant Willow
docs.text: "Everything is a canvas for beauty."

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Name Radiant Willow (prefers "Willow") Ancestry Leshy (Flower) Occupation Beautician, stylist, spa owner Location Dew Drop Petals, Willowshore

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Radiant Willow is a young, beautiful flower leshy who practically radiates enthusiasm. She runs Dew Drop Petals, a small salon and spa in Willowshore where she offers manicures, pedicures, hair styling, beard braiding, and fashion consulting. She's known for her singing and dancing, and will be performing at the Festival of Returning Spirits.

When she enters a room, she brings energy with her—skipping, singing lullabies, and immediately assessing everyone's beauty potential. She sees the world as a canvas waiting to be adorned.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Willow is irrepressibly cheerful, effusive, and persistent. She doesn't take "no" for an answer easily—at least not when it comes to offering her services. She believes passionately that everyone deserves to look beautiful, and she cannot understand why anyone would choose to be "drab."

Despite her bubbly exterior, she's an excellent listener. As she styles hair and files nails, people talk to her—and she hears all the gossip in town. She was coy about sharing what she knows, but hinted that a visit to her shop might loosen her tongue.

docs.title: Views on the Oni
docs.text: Willow is cautiously optimistic about the incoming mayor. She hopes the change might bring prosperity and give Willowshore something to smile about. She admires Magistrate Kurosawa's "gorgeous blue skin" but wishes he would smile more. She's reserving judgment until Mayor Masru actually arrives.

docs.title: Ginkgo

docs.title: Shogun Tsuneni
docs.text: The undisputed ruler of Chu Ye. No one has come close to challenging his power.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Name Tsuneni (TSOO-neh-nee) Title Shogun of Chu Ye Type Void Oni (Voidlord) Alignment Tyrannical Location Jyito (capital)

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Shogun Tsuneni is a void oni of immense power—the undisputed ruler of Chu Ye. He overthrew the old order when Imperial Lung Wa fell and has maintained his grip on the nation for a century. His rule is absolute; no challenger has ever come close to threatening his position.

He convenes a ruling council in Jyito once a year to discuss affairs of state—a lavish event designed to appeal to the hedonistic nature of oni, making attendance something officials desire rather than dread.

docs.title: Government
docs.text:
Tsuneni rules through two lieutenants who manage day-to-day governance:

  • Steward Imora (Storm Oni, Marshal) — Oversees the military
  • Steward Tanyo (Void Oni, Councilor) — Manages the bureaucracy

The ruling council contains several factions that Tsuneni enjoys pitting against each other:

Faction Leader Philosophy Daiyoku Uno (Caldera Oni) Militaristic; seeks to conquer all Tian Xia Shinkaze Shiga (Storm Oni) Isolationist; seeks spiritual redemption Hedonists Tamami (Village Oni) Pleasure-seekers; no interest in ruling

docs.title: Relevance to Willowshore
docs.text:
Willowshore has been without an oni mayor for generations—a small, forgotten village allowed to govern itself. Now, a new oni mayor is arriving, bringing Tsuneni's regime directly into the lives of the villagers for the first time in living memory.

The arrival has stirred unrest. The old ruling family refuses to participate in the traditional Revival of Friendship ceremony. Tensions are rising.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Someone in Willowshore always smiles, even when the news is bad. When misfortune befalls the oni or their allies, this person's expression brightens. When the new regime stumbles, they seem quietly pleased.

They are a member of the old ruling family—the de facto rulers who have been displaced by the arrival of the oni mayor. Unlike others who hide their resentment, this person wears their satisfaction openly, if subtly.

docs.title: The Secret
docs.text:
When they think no one is listening, they whisper: "I know the real ending."

This refers to the oldest story villagers tell about the forest shadows—a tale whose ending is never spoken aloud because it starts fights and embarrasses the ruling family. The Smiling One claims to know what really happened.

docs.title: Significance
docs.text: The Smiling One represents the old guard's quiet resistance to oni rule. They know secrets about Willowshore's past that others have forgotten or choose not to speak. Whether they will share this knowledge—and at what price—remains to be seen.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Yong is a young kitsune in his late twenties—fit and strong from years of working the forge. He runs Eternal Blaze Ironworks, Willowshore's only blacksmith shop. While not a master weaponsmith, he can craft serviceable weapons, tools, farming implements, bridles, and barding. Armor is beyond his current skill.

When the party met him, Yong was exhausted and frustrated. Magistrate Kurosawa had been piling work orders on him in preparation for the festival, leaving him little time for regular customers.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text: Yong is hardworking and practical, but clearly stressed by the demands of the oni regime. He expressed relief when the party indicated they weren't there on behalf of the magistrate. He loves his son Hong deeply and was terrified when he learned the boy was trapped in the burning warehouse.

docs.title: Hong
docs.text:
Yong's young son, described as rambunctious but not troublesome. Hong was caught in the warehouse fire along with Kimmy. Despite his playful nature, he's learning the trade and helps at the forge when he can. Yong had planned to give him a set of shuriken he'd crafted.

It was later revealed that Hong was hired by the Yeshou family to set the warehouse fire—a "prank" for 100 gold pieces. Yong did not know about this scheme; Hong acted to fund Yong's plan to leave Willowshore.

docs.title: The Party
docs.text: Yong is deeply grateful to the party for saving Hong's life. He offered to refund all the money they'd paid for their weapon orders as thanks—though the party did not take him up on this offer. He owes them a debt that weighs on him.

docs.title: Magistrate Kurosawa
docs.text: Yong clearly resents the workload the magistrate has imposed on him, though he's too cautious to express this openly. He does not want his son to get in trouble with the oni authorities.

docs.title: Plans to Leave
docs.text: Yong privately plans to leave Willowshore. He told Hong he "sees dark skies ahead" for the village and wants to relocate somewhere safer to re-establish his forge. The 100 gold Hong brought home could fund this plan, though Yong is cautious about the windfall—he intends to "pray to our elders and spirits" before deciding whether it's a boon or a darker omen.

docs.title: Boone
docs.text: A stranger from distant lands, drawn by curiosity to a town on the edge of change.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: PlayerChris AncestryDwarf ClassFighter BackgroundVeteran, outsider

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Boone is a dwarf—a rarity in Tian Xia, where his kind are almost unheard of. He arrived in Willowshore as a stranger wandering in from distant lands, his presence drawing curious and sometimes suspicious glances from locals who have never seen his like.

His children are grown. His old life is behind him. He's out looking for adventure, and rumors of a new oni taking control of this quiet village drew his curiosity. He wandered in to see what was happening—and found himself in the middle of something far more complex than he expected.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Boone is direct and uncomplicated in a way that contrasts sharply with Willowshore's web of secrets and unspoken traditions. He is not a diplomat. He has no idea what's really happening with the oni and the ruling family's tensions. But he knows how to fight, and he's been itching to get back into the swing of things after years of peaceful retirement.

He likes hitting things. It's been a while, but some skills never fade.

docs.title: Background
docs.text: Boone is a veteran of a war fought long ago—the same conflict that Ginkgo and Donkey remember with their private memorial. But Boone was on the opposite side. None of them feel like winners. The war was like that—nobody came out ahead, and everyone carries the weight of what was lost.

docs.title: Why He Came to Willowshore
docs.text:
Willowshore had been quiet for decades—a declining village that the wider world had largely forgotten. Then word spread that an oni mayor was coming, claiming power after generations of absence. Boone heard the rumors and grew curious. What kind of change was coming to this forgotten place?

He wandered in to find out. He's still figuring out the answer.

docs.title: Ginkgo & Donkey
docs.text: Boone, Ginkgo, and Donkey are all veterans of the same war—though Boone fought on the opposing side. Despite this, they share an understanding that transcends old battle lines. All three see themselves as losers in a conflict that had no real winners. It was their Vietnam.

docs.title: Da Baishan
docs.text: "The mountain does not rush, does not shout, and does not move without cause."

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: PlayerBraedon AncestryOrc ClassInvestigator BackgroundDetective among the orc clans

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Da Baishan (大白山, "Big White Mountain") is an orc investigator who grew up in the cavern networks where the orc clans of Chu Ye carved their homes into the bones of the earth. Unlike many of his kin, Baishan was educated deliberately—learning clan histories, ancestral customs, and the unwritten laws that kept blood feuds from becoming extinction events.

Among his people, strength is respected, but endurance is revered. Baishan learned early that the strongest orc is not the one who strikes first, but the one who understands why the strike is coming.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Baishan is scholarly and observant—somewhat surprising for his brutish appearance. He trusts patterns over proclamations and approaches problems methodically. When investigating, he doesn't ask who is guilty—he asks who benefited, who stayed silent, and who changed their habits afterward.

He does not threaten. He explains. And when the truth surfaces, as it always does, Baishan is already standing where it will break.

docs.title: Why He Came to Willowshore
docs.text:
When the oni appeared—after generations of absence—and overthrew the old ruling order, Baishan did not celebrate. Power that arrives suddenly and claims inevitability always hides a cost. While others accepted the new hierarchy, Baishan watched. He listened. And when answers did not come, he left the caverns to investigate for himself.

The trail led him to Willowshore. He finds the oni's "I've always been here" posture deeply suspicious and seeks to uncover the truth behind their sudden return.

docs.title: Littlefinger
docs.text: Baishan caught Littlefinger committing a crime against the oni—cleanly, unmistakably. The evidence was sound, the motive obvious. Rather than turn him in, Baishan recognized a shared suspicion. An alliance formed, not from trust, but from aligned doubt.

docs.title: Ginkgo
docs.text: By the river, Baishan witnessed something that unsettled him deeply: a spirit killing a mortal in full view of the living world. He and Ginkgo stood as witnesses. Ginkgo's leshy beliefs—that death fed life, that decay was not corruption but transformation—stood in stark opposition to Willowshore's funerary laws. Against local custom, Baishan agreed to hide the body in the forest and allow it to return to the cycle. It was a calculated risk. One he still weighs.

docs.title: Donkey
docs.text: At a tavern, Baishan crossed paths with Donkey, an ancient elf who spoke a truth so carefully framed that it led Baishan into public embarrassment. The statement was technically accurate—and deeply misleading. Baishan does not forget such things. Deception masked as wisdom is still deception. Yet he respects Donkey's knowledge and considers him a valuable, if unreliable, source of information.

docs.title: Donkey
docs.text: Nobody knows why he's called Donkey. Including himself.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: PlayerDavid AncestryElf (ancient, appears human) ClassWizard BackgroundVillage witch, herbalist

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Donkey is impossibly old. Nobody knows exactly how old—there's definitely some human back in the woodpile somewhere, and people aren't really sure if he's an elf or a human anymore. He's been around Willowshore forever. The name "Donkey" just came about at some point; he didn't correct people, they didn't ask, and it stuck.

Nobody really knows where he lives. He seems to just live off the land, appearing in town every so often to trade herbs and offer help to those who need it. He's something of a village witch—everyone seems to have had at least one conversation with him, though he doesn't talk much.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Donkey speaks rarely, but when he does, his words carry weight—though not always in the way the listener expects. He has a habit of telling truths that are technically accurate but carefully framed to lead people exactly where he wants them to go. Whether this is mischief, wisdom, or something else entirely remains unclear.

He observes more than he participates, watching the town's affairs with the patience of someone who has seen cycles repeat many times over.

docs.title: Role in Willowshore
docs.text:
Donkey serves as an informal resource for the village:

  • Herbalist — Brings herbs from the forest to trade
  • Advisor — Helps those who seek him out, in his own way
  • Living memory — Knows everyone and their family histories through sheer longevity

docs.title: Ginkgo
docs.text: Donkey and Ginkgo share a private tradition—a memorial for a war they both fought in. Once a year, they take time away to remember those who fell. The details remain between them.

docs.title: Boone
docs.text: Boone fought on the opposite side of the same war. Despite this, there's a shared understanding among all three veterans—none of them feel like winners. The war left its mark on everyone.

docs.title: Da Baishan
docs.text:
Donkey has become one of Da Baishan's sources of information in Willowshore. However, their relationship is complicated. Donkey once told Da Baishan something that was technically true but incomplete, leading the investigator into a dangerous situation. Da Baishan emerged, but he's "still slightly miffed" and doesn't fully trust the old wizard—even as he respects his knowledge.

"You want to play hardball in Willowshore? I just wanted to see if you got what it takes."

docs.text: "Death is not an ending. It is a return to the cycle."

docs.title: Overview

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Ginkgo is a fungus leshy who serves as a scout, collecting information about the oni presence in Chu Ye. As a leshy, he is connected to other members of his kind through the mycelium network—a vast underground web of fungal communication that spans the forests.

His fungal nature gives him a unique perspective on life and death. To Ginkgo, decay is not corruption but transformation. Death feeds life. Everything is part of one great ecosystem, endlessly cycling.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Ginkgo approaches the world through the lens of ecology and natural cycles. He is uncertain about spirits—their existence doesn't quite fit with his worldview—but he cannot deny that something is happening in Willowshore that defies easy explanation.

He is pragmatic about death in ways that others find unsettling. Where villagers see tragedy, Ginkgo sees the continuation of the cycle.

docs.title: Beliefs
docs.text:
Ginkgo's philosophy centers on the interconnectedness of all living things:

  • Death is transformation — Bodies should return to the earth, feeding new life
  • The mycelium connects all — Through the fungal network, information and nutrients flow between all living things
  • Spirits are uncertain — He neither fully believes nor disbelieves, but observes

docs.title: Donkey
docs.text: Ginkgo and Donkey share a private tradition—a memorial for a battle they both fought in long ago. On this day each year, they take time away from others to remember. The details of this war remain private between them.

docs.title: Boone
docs.text: Boone fought on the opposite side of the same war that Ginkgo and Donkey commemorate. There are no winners in their shared history—all three consider themselves on the losing side. This creates an unusual bond of mutual understanding among embittered veterans.

docs.title: Da Baishan
docs.text: By the river one night, Ginkgo and Da Baishan witnessed a spirit kill a person. According to local legend, death by a spirit means the body could return or be controlled unless disposed of through special rites. Ginkgo, following his beliefs about the natural cycle, convinced Da Baishan to help hide the body in the forest instead—allowing it to decompose naturally and return to the earth. This shared secret binds them.

docs.text:
Littlefinger is a halfling rogue with connections to Willowshore's ruling family—whether through marriage, blood, or some other tie remains to be seen. When the family fell on hard times and their influence waned, he turned to thievery to survive.

But he's not just any thief. Littlefinger fancies himself a Robin Hood type: stealing from the oni and their collaborators to help the common folk of Willowshore. There's never an autocrat for good, they say—but maybe there can be a thief for good.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Littlefinger is cunning and opportunistic, with halfling luck on his side. He's drawn to schemes and capers, always looking for the next mark—preferably someone who deserves to lose what they have.

He has a strong sense that the oni are bad for Willowshore, and he's willing to take risks to undermine them however he can.

docs.title: Skills & Abilities
docs.text:
As an Eager Scofflaw, Littlefinger has honed a particular set of skills:

  • Halfling Luck — Fortune favors the bold (and the small)
  • Sneak Attack — Strike from the shadows
  • Thieves' Tools — No lock is truly secure
  • Deception & Stealth — The art of not being where people think you are

docs.title: Da Baishan
docs.text: Da Baishan caught Littlefinger in the act—breaking into something connected to the oni. The evidence was clear, the crime undeniable. But instead of turning him in, Da Baishan recognized a kindred suspicion of the new regime. They formed an alliance, not from trust, but from aligned purpose. Forged in crime.

docs.title: The Ruling Family
docs.text: Littlefinger has ties to Willowshore's de facto rulers—the family that refuses to participate in the Revival of Friendship for the new oni mayor. The exact nature of this connection (marriage, blood, employment) remains unclear.

docs.title: Session Zero (2026-01-16)
docs.text:
• Character created
  • Established as a halfling rogue with ties to the ruling family
  • Caught stealing from oni-related targets by Da Baishan; formed an alliance
  • Expressed interest in Robin Hood-style theft to help Willowshore's common folk

docs.title: Session One (2026-01-30)
docs.text:
• Led the way into the burning warehouse despite misgivings
  • Took damage from exploding fireworks and falling shelves
  • Used Halfling Luck to save Hong; threw himself over the boy to shield him from debris
  • Purchased shuriken from Yong; traded dagger to Da Baishan for an orcish sap
  • Recruited as a deputy by Magistrate Kurosawa
  • Booked a room at Silver Mist Lodge under his name
  • Plans to use his connections to investigate the ruling family

docs.title: Session Two (2026-02-05)
docs.text:
• Used his street smarts to coax Hong's confession: "We've all done stuff for girls, Hong"
  • Attempted intimidation (rolled 6—"I'm just a little guy")
  • Jokingly tried to reduce Hong's payment ("We'll make sure you get your 90 gold pieces")
  • Palmed a gold coin from Hong's bag (Thievery 14)—Donkey and Ginkgo noticed, but the blacksmith family didn't
  • Couldn't bring himself to actually steal from a kid; handed the full satchel back
  • Rolled a nat 20 on initiative in the graveyard combat
  • Took 6 damage from the undead cat's pounce attack
  • Struggled with rapier attacks against the cat but killed it with a shuriken to the hollow eye
  • Flanked the zombie with a thrown shuriken hit
  • Moved tactically to set up flank positions during combat

docs.title: Session Three (2026-02-12)
docs.text:
• Stayed behind in Willowshore while the party ventured into the Dark Woods—scouting the town, watching for the magistrate's return, and protecting the graveyard in case of further undead activity
  • Reunited with the party at Silver Mist Inn in the evening
  • Heard the (embellished) account of the party's adventure: "three bears" and "every crossbow bolt struck true"
